title: Romanian government in crisis after junior partner exits coalition
text:
Romanian Prime Minister Viorica Dăncilă | Daniel Mihailescu/AFP via Getty Images Romanian government in crisis after junior partner exits coalition The ruling Social Democrats say they will negotiate for support to continue governing.

The future of Romania's Social Democrat-led government is in limbo after its junior partner decided to exit the coalition on Monday.

Romanian Prime Minister Viorica Dăncilă said in a Facebook post that her PSD party would continue to govern despite the liberal ALDE party's withdrawal from the coalition.

"For us, this is an incomprehensible decision on the part of ALDE," Dăncilă said in a video statement Monday evening.

The PSD now no longer has the required majority in parliament, leaving the prime minister vulnerable to a confidence motion.

But Dăncilă is counting on the support of some ALDE lawmakers who want to remain in government as well as the backing of some lawmakers from Pro Romania, an opposition group formed by former PSD Prime Minister Victor Ponta.

According to the Romanian constitution, the prime minister must now call a confidence vote within 45 days.

The breakup of the ruling coalition comes on the heels of a tumultuous time in Romanian politics. For the past year, Dăncilă's government has faced protests and international condemnation over concerns that the country is backsliding on rule of law and combatting corruption.

ALDE leader Călin Popescu Tăriceanu said his party was breaking ties with the PSD to form an alliance with Pro Romania and back Mircea Diaconu, an actor and former MEP, to become president in the upcoming November election.

Pro Romania largely consists of former PSD members who defected from the Social Democrats over disagreements with former leader Liviu Dragnea. The new party fared well in May’s European Parliament election, securing spots for two MEPs, including outgoing European Regional Commissioner Corina Crețu, who also joined Pro Romania after leaving the PSD.

Next steps

Tăriceanu also said he would resign from his job of president of the Senate at the beginning of the next parliamentary session in September. The ALDE leader initially wanted to run for president as the ruling coalition's sole candidate, but the PSD instead decided to back Prime Minister Dăncilă for the job.

Foreign Affairs Minister Ramona Mănescu, one of ALDE's four Cabinet members, said she would not resign despite the political consequences. Tăriceanu said he would exclude from the party anyone who does not follow his decision.

According to the Romanian constitution, the prime minister must now call a confidence vote within 45 days.

Should the opposition call for a confidence vote earlier, Tăriceanu said his party would do what any opposition party does and vote against the government. The National Liberal Party (PNL), an opposition group, said earlier Monday that it would put forward such a motion, but did not say when. The PNL is aiming for early elections.

Mihai Fifor, the interim internal affairs minister, said the PSD would negotiate with all political groups in order to remain in power, Romanian media reported. He added that the PSD ending up in the opposition "could be an alternative."

Dăncilă said that if a vote of no confidence were to pass, her party would "obey the vote of the parliament."
